legal_basis: Notice is given under section 1 of the Statistics of Trade Act 1947.
title: Business Enterprise Research and Development

title.text: You are completing this for {trad_as} ({ru_name})

description.text: If the company details or structure have changed contact us on {telephone_number_link} or email {email_link}

list: You have been selected to complete the Business Enterprise Research and Development (BERD) survey.
The purpose of this survey is to collect expenditure and employment figures relating to Research and Development (R&D) activities.

The survey contributes to the measurement of resources devoted to research and development in the United Kingdom (UK). These figures are used in analysis and decision making by government, businesses and international organisations and are collected to allow the UK to be internationally comparable with other R&D performing countries.
If your business did not perform or purchase any R&D, you are still required to complete the relevant sections in this questionnaire.
Report R&D expenditure figures regardless of whether tax credits have been claimed.
Data should relate to all sites in the UK. The UK includes England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland but excludes the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man.
We will treat your data securely and confidentially.

contents.description: This questionnaire is divided into sections, which ask for information about:
This section asks about the period for which your business will be reporting.

Your return period should cover the calendar year 2022. If no figures are available for that 12 month period, your return should relate to a business year that ends between 6 April 2022 and 5 April 2023.

This section asks for information about the R&D that your business has undertaken either for yourself or for a customer. This is the total cost of R&D conducted by your business, regardless of the source of funds or their treatment within your business's accounts.
This includes:

list: funding for expenditure on in-house R&D

questions.question: Purchase of R&D conducted outside of the business

contents.description: This section asks for information about the purchase of R&D outside of the business. This can include R&D work both within and outside of the UK as well as work originally commissioned by the UK Government.

questions.question: Number of employees working on R&D

contents.description: This section asks for information about how many employees worked on R&D during the reporting period and how many full-time equivalents work on R&D.
This section asks for information about:

list: the postcodes of all the workplaces within the business where in-house R&D is performed
the percentage of the business's total R&D carried out at each workplace

contents.description: All workplaces covering 100% of the business's in-house R&D should be reported.
R&D covers three types of activity:

R&D comprises creative and systematic work undertaken in order to increase the stock of knowledge, and in order to devise new applications of available knowledge. R&D activity must have elements of all of these five criteria:

list: Novel - to be aimed at new findings
Creative - to be based on original, not obvious, concepts and hypotheses
Uncertain - to be uncertain about the final outcome
Transferable or reproducible - to lead to results that could possibly be reproduced

contents.description: Below are some basic guidelines to help define and measure R&D for completion of this survey. In some cases, you may need to apply judgement when compiling figures. Informed estimates are acceptable. Further information can be found in the Frascati Manual (this link opens in a new tab), which is the international source of methodology for collecting and using R&D statistics.
R&D covers three types of activity:

R&D comprises creative and systematic work undertaken in order to increase the stock of knowledge, and in order to devise new applications of available knowledge. R&D activity must have elements of all of these five criteria:

list: novel - to be aimed at new findings
creative - to be based on original, not obvious, concepts and hypotheses
uncertain - to be uncertain about the final outcome
transferable or reproducible - to lead to results that could possibly be reproduced
clinical trials phases I, II and III
social sciences, arts and humanities research work, such as, development of ethical processes, behavioural insights and linguistics
research into and original development, or substantial modification, of computer software, such as, new programming languages and new operating systems
design, construction and operation of prototypes where the main objective is technical testing or to make further improvements
construction and operation of pilot plants while still in the experimental phase and the primary purpose of operation is non commercial
'feedback R&D' directed at solving problems occurring beyond the original R&D phase, such as, the resolution of technical problems arising in initial production runs

contents.description: Unless used primarily as part of, or for the support of R&D projects, the following are excluded:

list: prospecting, exploring or drilling for minerals, petroleum or natural gas
policy related studies, management studies, efficiency studies
general purpose or routine data collection
routine computer programming, systems maintenance or software application
commercial, legal and administrative aspects of patenting, copyrighting or licensing activities
specialised routine medical care, for example, routine pathology services

contents.description: R&D ends when the work is no longer experimental, for example, when the material or product is substantially developed and the primary objective is to:

list: plan for pre-production and undertake pre-production activities, such as, demonstration of commercial viability, tooling up and trial production runs
get production or control systems working smoothly

contents.description: If the primary objective is to make further technical improvements, then the work is still defined as R&D.

description.text: You will be asked to report for {ref_p_start_date} to {ref_p_end_date}. If you are unable to provide figures for this period, you will have the option to choose your own dates.

title.text: Are you able to report for the calendar year, {ref_p_start_date} to {ref_p_end_date}?

description: Your return should relate to the calendar year 2022.

contents.description: Traded for part of the year?
Please select 'no, I need to report for a different period'
Cannot report for this calendar year?

options.label: No, I need to report for a different period
options.value: No, I need to report for a different period

in: Yes, I can report for this period

question.title: What dates will you be reporting for?
description: If figures are not available for the calendar year 2022, your return should relate to a business year that ends between 6 April 2022 and 5 April 2023.

contents.description: Only traded for a part of the year?
Please provide figures for the period in which you were trading.
Only commenced trading during 2022?
Your return should cover the period from the commencement of your business until 31 December 2022 or, alternatively, any date up to 5 April 2023.
Ceased trading during 2022?
Your return should cover the period 1 January 2022 to the date you ceased to trade or, alternatively, from the beginning of your last business year up to the cessation date.

contents.description: Include:
Exclude:

title.text: Of the {noncapital_expenditure_on_all_materials_supplies_equipment_and_services_for_civil_research_and_development} non-capital expenditure on all civil R&D materials, supplies, equipment and services, how much did your business spend on the following?

description.text:
You are reporting civil R&D for sector {sectors}.

Values should sum to your business's total non-capital expenditure on all civil R&D materials, supplies, equipment and services.

Informed estimates are acceptable.

contents.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

answers.label: Purchase of materials for civil Research and Development
answers.description: Include supplies and equipment, water, fuel, materials for labs, such as, chemicals and reference materials, such as, books. Exclude VAT.

answers.label: Purchase of services for civil Research and Development
answers.description: Include expenditure for on-site consultants, prototypes or models made outside the organisation and indirect services hired or purchased. Exclude VAT.

contents.description: This refers to:

list: repair and maintenance of buildings or equipment
subscriptions to libraries or scientific societies

answers.label: Non-capital expenditure for civil Research and Development related to basic research
answers.description: Include work undertaken primarily to acquire new knowledge without a specific application in mind

answers.label: Non-capital expenditure for civil Research and Development related to applied research
answers.description: Include work undertaken to acquire new knowledge with a specific application in mind

answers.label: Non-capital expenditure for civil Research and Development related to experimental development
answers.description: Include work using the results from basic or applied research for the purpose of creating new or improved products or processes

title.text: For the reporting period, of the {ptotal_capital_and_noncapital_expenditure_on_inhouse_civil_rampdp} total expenditure for in-house civil R&D, how much of your business's R&D assets are, or will be, owned by the following?

description.text:
You are reporting civil R&D for sector {sectors}.

For this question, the value of the R&D assets your business produces should be allocated to owners, or future and final owners.

Values should sum to your business's total in-house expenditure for civil R&D.

Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

Informed estimates are acceptable. It may be necessary to consider individual R&D projects and then aggregate results.

contents.description: Exclude any cost plus element

answers.label: Your UK business
answers.description: Include your parent company, other subsidiary companies operating within the UK, or R&D covered by patents owned by your UK business

answers.label: The UK Government
answers.description: Include UK government departments, their agencies and non-departmental public bodies, for example, NHS, MoD, Department of Health, Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy, the Scottish or Welsh Governments

answers.label: Other UK business enterprises
answers.description: Include non-profit organisations serving businesses

answers.label: Other UK organisations
answers.description: Include higher education establishments and private non-profit organisations serving households, education establishments and trade unions

answers.label: Any other businesses or organisations outside the UK
answers.description: Include businesses within your group but outside the UK, for example, funded from your parent company or other subsidiary companies operating outside the UK; other business enterprises outside of the UK; non-UK governments; international organisations, for example, World Trade Organisation or NATO and the Commission of the European Union

answers.label: Not owned and freely available in-house Research and Development
answers.description: Include in-house R&D which is developed and published and made freely available for others to use. For example, publications in journals or on the internet, and R&D with no intellectual property protection, such as patents and copyrights

guidance.show_guidance: How you might answer this question
guidance.hide_guidance: How you might answer this question

contents.description: If the R&D performed in the reporting period is, or is expected to eventually be, subject to intellectual property protection, such as, patents and copyrights, the holder of that protection is the owner.
If a number of organisations will own the R&D assets, the in-house expenditure should be divided and allocated to the relevant owners.

If ownership is contractually divided between different owners, divide the in-house R&D in accordance with the percentage ownership. For example, 60% is owned by your UK business and 40% owned by the UK Government, please use these percentages to divide the in-house R&D expenditure between answers.

If no contractual arrangements exist, the value of the assets should be divided according to your best estimate of their use. For example, if your business and another organisation are both owners, but your business will use the assets more, ownership should be allocated accordingly. If the use cannot be estimated, the assets should be divided equally between the owners.

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, what was your business's gross non-capital expenditure on salaries and wages for defence R&D?

description.text: You are reporting defence R&D for sector {sectors}.

contents.description: Include:

title.text: Of the {noncapital_expenditure_on_all_materials_supplies_equipment_and_services_for_defence_research_and_development} non-capital expenditure on all defence R&D materials, supplies, equipment and services, how much did your business spend on the following?

description.text:
You are reporting defence R&D for sector {sectors}.

Values should sum to your business's total non-capital expenditure on all R&D materials, supplies, equipment and services.

Informed estimates are acceptable.

contents.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

answers.label: Purchase of materials for defence Research and Development
answers.description: Include supplies and equipment, water, fuel, materials for labs, such as, chemicals and reference materials, such as, books. Exclude VAT.

answers.label: Purchase of services for Research and Development
answers.description: Include expenditure for on-site consultants, prototypes or models made outside the organisation and indirect services hired or purchased. Exclude VAT.

contents.description: This refers to:

subscriptions to libraries or scientific societies

answers.label: Non-capital expenditure for defence Research and Development related to applied research
answers.description: Include work undertaken to acquire new knowledge with a specific application in mind

answers.label: Non-capital expenditure for defence Research and Development related to experimental development
answers.description: Include work using the results from basic or applied research for the purpose of creating new or improved products or processes

description.text:

Informed estimates are acceptable.

contents.description: Include contracts, grants or donations in the form of money or any other resources, such as, venture capital

answers.label: Own funds from within the UK
answers.description: Include funding from your parent company or other subsidiary companies operating within the UK

answers.label: The UK Government
answers.description: Include funding from, or originating within, UK government departments, their agencies and non-departmental public bodies, for example, NHS, MoD, BEIS, the Scottish or Welsh Governments.  Exclude European funding departments, such as, the Welsh European Funding Office (WEFO)

answers.label: Other UK business enterprises
answers.description: Include private non-profit organisations serving businesses

answers.label: UK non-profit organisations
answers.description: Include trade unions and private non-profit organisations serving households

answers.label: UK higher education establishments

title.text: For the reporting period, of the {ptotal_capital_and_non_capital_expenditure_for_inhouse_defence_rampdp} total expenditure for in-house defence R&D, how much of your business's R&D assets are, or will be, owned by the following?

description.text:
You are reporting defence R&D for sector {sectors}.

For this question, the value of the R&D assets your business produces should be allocated to owners, or future and final owners.

Values should sum to your business's total in-house expenditure for defence R&D.

Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

Informed estimates are acceptable. It may be necessary to consider individual R&D projects and then aggregate results.

contents.description: Exclude any cost plus element

answers.label: Your UK business
answers.description: Include your parent company, other subsidiary companies operating within the UK, or R&D covered by patents owned by your UK business

answers.label: The UK Government
answers.description: Include UK government departments, their agencies and non departmental public bodies, for example, NHS, MoD, Department of Health, Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy, the Scottish or Welsh Governments

answers.label: Other UK business enterprises
answers.description: Include non profit organisations serving businesses

answers.label: Other UK organisations
answers.description: Include higher education establishments and private non profit organisations serving households, education establishments and trade unions

answers.label: Any other businesses or organisations outside the UK
answers.description: Include businesses within your group but outside the UK, for example, funded from your parent company or other subsidiary companies operating outside the UK; other business enterprises outside of the UK; non-UK governments; international organisations, for example, World Trade Organisation or NATO and the Commission of the European Union

answers.label: Not owned and freely available in-house Research and Development
answers.description: Include in-house R&D which is developed and published and made freely available for others to use. For example, publications in journals or on the internet, and R&D with no intellectual property protection, such as, patents and copyrights

guidance.show_guidance: How you might answer this question
guidance.hide_guidance: How you might answer this question

contents.description: If the R&D performed in the reporting period is, or is expected to eventually be, subject to intellectual property protection, such as, patents and copyrights, the holder of that protection is the owner.
If a number of organisations will own the R&D assets, the in-house expenditure should be divided and allocated to the relevant owners.

If ownership is contractually divided between different owners, divide the in-house R&D in accordance with the percentage ownership. For example, 60% is owned by your UK business and 40% owned by the UK Government, please use these percentages to divide the in-house R&D expenditure between answers.

If no contractual arrangements exist, the value of the assets should be divided according to your best estimate of their use. For example, if your business and another organisation are both owners, but your business will use the assets more, ownership should be allocated accordingly. If the use cannot be estimated, the assets should be divided equally between the owners.

All expenditure should be reported as gross unless otherwise stated.
Exclude any expenditure reported as in-house expenditure.

sections.title: Purchase of R&D conducted outside of the business

title.text: {item-text-e4f472e4-9aaa-409e-9717-f7c6d1f3f8fc}

content.title: Purchase of R&D conducted outside of the business

contents.description: This section asks for information about the purchase of R&D outside of the business. This can include work both within and outside of the UK as well as work originally commissioned by Government. It also includes the total cost of non-capital expenditure carried out by your business in the UK, regardless of the source of funds or their treatment within your business's accounts.
All expenditure should be reported as gross unless otherwise stated.
Exclude any expenditure reported as in-house expenditure.

title.text: Which of the following types of R&D were purchased by your business in relation to sector {sectors}?

options.label: Both, civil and defence Research and Development
options.value: Both, civil and defence Research and Development

contents.description: This refers to all R&D carried out primarily for defence or military reasons, even if civil use is made of it at a later date.

sections.title: Number of employees working on R&D

content.title: Number of employees working on R&D

contents.description: This section asks for information about how many employees and full-time equivalents work on R&D.

An employee is anyone aged 16 or over that your organisation directly pays from its payroll, in return for carrying out a full time or part-time job or being on a training scheme. Each employee should have a contract of employment.

question.title: On 1 December 2022, how many employees working on R&D were researchers?
description: 'Researchers' refers to employees who are engaged in conception or creation of new knowledge, products, methods and systems. For example, PhD students, graduates and scientists.

contents.description: Include:

list: all workers paid directly from this business's payroll(s)
those temporarily absent but still being paid, for example, on maternity or paternity leave

contents.description: Exclude:

list: agency workers and contractors paid directly from the agency payroll or contractor company

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, how many full-time equivalent employees working on R&D were researchers?

description: 'Researchers' refers to employees who are engaged in conception or creation of new knowledge, products, methods and systems. For example, PhD students, graduates and scientists.

contents.description: Include:

list: all workers paid directly from this business's payroll(s)
those temporarily absent but still being paid, for example, on maternity or paternity leave

contents.description: Exclude:

list: agency workers and contractors paid directly from the agency payroll or contractor company
former employees only receiving a pension
working owners who are not paid directly from this business's payroll(s)

contents.description: One full-time equivalent (FTE) may be thought of as one person-year.
For example, a person who normally spends 30% of their time on R&D and the rest on other activities should be considered as 0.3 FTE.
Similarly, if a full-time R&D worker is employed at an R&D unit for only six months, this results in the FTE of 0.5.

answers.label: Number of full-time equivalent researchers working on civil Research and Development
Number of full-time equivalent researchers working on defence Research and Development
